article_title: Obamacare's insured struggle with premiums as 2015 enrollment begins
article_text:
Obamacare's insured struggle with premiums as 2015 enrollment begins

Photo: Eric Kayne Counselor Yvette Escalante helped people sign up for insurance...

Darrell Shepard, 48, of Houston struggles to pay his monthly insurance premium for coverage he bought in the 2014 health insurance marketplace that was created by the Affordable Care Act. On the other hand, his health care costs have been much lower this year because of that insurance.

article_metadata.description: Darrell Shepard, 48, of Houston struggles to pay his monthly insurance premium for coverage he bought in the 2014 health insurance marketplace that was created by the Affordable Care Act.  Nearly 734,000 Texans - many of them lower-income, previously uninsured working people - signed up during the marketplace's 2014 open enrollment, and all but 15 percent of them qualified for subsidies that reduced their monthly premium bills, the Center for Public Policy Priorities in Austin reports.  With more than 137,000 sign-ups, Harris County reported the state's highest share of overall enrollment for 2014, according to Enroll America, a health insurance coalition.  "The affordability of health insurance marketplace plans, even with subsidies, has been an open question from the outset," Elena Marks, president and CEO of Houston's Episcopal Health Foundation, said in a written statement at the time the survey came out.  [...] the penalty for declining to purchase health insurance increases in 2015 to $325 per person or 2 percent of family income, whichever is greater.  [...] many will need assistance navigating the system because they have little understanding of how health insurance works or whether they qualify for premium subsidies.  "The (Affordable Care Act) is clearly working to reduce the number of uninsured people," said Ken Janda, president and CEO of the Houston-based managed care organization Community Health Choice.  Almost all Texans who sought information about the 2014 health insurance marketplace turned to the federal website, healthcare.gov, or the government's call center, according to research conducted by Marks and Ho.  Garza researched more than a dozen options available in the Houston area and repeatedly phoned the federal marketplace call center before selecting a plan that would provide the best coverage for the couple's money.  Shepard's marketplace plan includes all services provided at the Legacy Community Health Services clinic where he seeks care for diabetes, high cholesterol and high blood pressure.
article_metadata.author.name: By Lora Hines
